summary_llm:
Certainly! Here is a **very detailed summary** of the plot of the complete text you provided (Jane Eyre by Charlotte Brontë). This summary will cover all the main events, situations, character developments, and the conclusion strictly according to the text you gave. There will be no outside context, analysis, or philosophical discussion—only a chronological and comprehensive recounting of the story's events.

---

## Detailed Plot Summary of *Jane Eyre*

### Childhood at Gateshead

The story opens with ten-year-old Jane Eyre, an orphan, living at Gateshead Hall with her aunt, Mrs. Reed, and her cousins John, Eliza, and Georgiana Reed. She is excluded from the family and subject to constant mistreatment and bullying, especially from her cousin John. After being unjustly accused and struck by John, Jane finally retaliates, and as punishment, she is locked in the frightening "red-room," where her uncle died. Overcome with terror and despair, Jane screams and faints.

Regaining consciousness, Jane finds herself attended by the apothecary, Mr. Lloyd. He listens kindly to her troubles and later recommends to Mrs. Reed that Jane be sent away to school—an idea Mrs. Reed eagerly accepts. Jane later confronts Mrs. Reed, expressing her feelings about her aunt's cruelty.

### Lowood School

Jane is sent to Lowood Institution, a strict charity school for orphan girls managed by the harsh Mr. Brocklehurst. The girls endure cold, poor food (burnt porridge), and frequent humiliations. Jane develops a close friendship with Helen Burns, an older girl who offers her philosophical and religious comfort in the face of injustice. Miss Temple, the caring superintendent, believes in Jane’s innocence after she is publicly shamed by Mr. Brocklehurst.

Lowood suffers a typhus epidemic, claiming many lives, including Helen Burns. With public exposure of the school's conditions, improvements are made. Jane thrives academically and becomes a teacher at Lowood for two years after graduation, until Miss Temple marries and leaves. Feeling lonely and restless, Jane decides to seek a new position as a governess.

### Thornfield Hall

Jane advertises and is hired at Thornfield Hall to educate Adèle, a young French girl. The housekeeper, Mrs. Fairfax, is kind and welcoming, and Adèle is lively, though not especially gifted. Jane soon meets her employer, Mr. Rochester—abrupt, dark, and enigmatic—when she helps him after his horse slips on ice. Mr. Rochester soon returns to Thornfield and begins to show Jane unusual attention.

Jane becomes increasingly captivated by Rochester, who delights in talking with her and values her intellect. Odd occurrences at Thornfield—strange laughter, a fire set in Mr. Rochester's room (from which Jane saves him), the mysterious seamstress Grace Poole—disturb Jane. One day, Rochester leaves to visit friends, and soon after, a party of wealthy guests, including the beautiful Blanche Ingram, arrives at Thornfield.

Jane believes Rochester intends to marry Blanche and thus prepares herself emotionally for disappointment. Among the guests is Mr. Mason, who is attacked in the night. Jane and Rochester tend to Mason’s injuries in secret, and Mason leaves, bound to silence.

### The Gypsy and the Proposal

A gypsy woman visits the house, telling fortunes. She turns out to be Rochester in disguise, and through this ruse, he reveals his knowledge of Jane’s feelings. Soon after, Jane is called back to Gateshead, where Mrs. Reed, on her deathbed, reveals she concealed a letter from Jane’s uncle, John Eyre, who wished to adopt her. Mrs. Reed shows no remorse and dies shortly afterwards.

Jane returns to Thornfield, where Rochester behaves warmly toward her. In the garden, he professes his love and proposes marriage. Jane, overjoyed, accepts.

### Broken Wedding and Escape

Strange incidents persist: Jane’s wedding veil is rent by a mysterious woman in her room. On the wedding day, the ceremony is interrupted by Mason and a solicitor, who reveal that Rochester is already married to Bertha Mason, a violent, insane woman kept locked in Thornfield’s attic, cared for by Grace Poole. Rochester admits everything and pleads with Jane to stay as his companion, but Jane refuses to become his mistress and flees in the night.

### Destitution and New Home

Jane leaves Thornfield with barely any money. She travels until destitute, ultimately collapsing on the moors. She is taken in by St. John Rivers and his sisters, Diana and Mary, who care for her. Jane adopts the alias "Jane Elliott." She bonds with the Rivers family, who are revealed to be her cousins when her uncle dies and leaves her a fortune of £20,000. Jane insists on sharing the inheritance equally with her cousins.

St. John offers Jane a position as a schoolmistress in the town of Morton. She takes it and becomes beloved by her pupils and neighbors.

### St. John’s Proposal and the Supernatural Summons

St. John, a missionary, proposes marriage to Jane—not for love, but for partnership in his missionary work in India. Jane refuses, insisting she cannot marry without love. St. John persists, and Jane is nearly persuaded by a sense of duty, but at this climactic moment, she supernaturally hears Rochester’s voice calling her name. Jane, convinced he needs her, determines to return to Thornfield.

### Return to Mr. Rochester

Jane returns to Thornfield and finds it a burned ruin. She learns from a local innkeeper that Bertha Mason set fire to the house and leapt to her death. Rochester, in trying to save her, lost his sight and a hand. He now lives at Ferndean, a nearby manor.

Jane finds Rochester at Ferndean, blind and despairing. She reveals herself, and they are reunited. Rochester proposes again; Jane joyfully accepts.

### Conclusion

Jane and Rochester marry quietly. His sight partially returns in one eye, enough to see their first son. They are blissfully happy. Diana and Mary marry and live nearby. St. John remains unmarried and devotes himself to missionary work in India, where Jane hears from him through occasional letters.

---

## Character Fates

- **Jane Eyre**: Orphan, mistreated, becomes a governess, endures hardship, finds love and happiness as Rochester’s wife.
- **Edward Rochester**: Jane’s employer and later husband; blinded and maimed in the fire but ultimately joyfully reunited with Jane.
- **St. John Rivers**: Jane’s stern cousin, a missionary, whose marriage proposal Jane refuses; he never marries.
- **Diana and Mary Rivers**: Jane’s kind, intellectual cousins; both marry and are happy.
- **Bertha Mason**: Rochester’s insane wife, dies in the Thornfield fire.
- **Adèle**: Jane’s pupil, cared for and educated by Jane, grows up to be a pleasant, educated young woman.
- **Mrs. Fairfax**: Thornfield’s housekeeper, happy for Jane when she marries Rochester.

---

## Conclusion

Jane is finally rewarded for her endurance, integrity, and courage. After years of struggle, loneliness, and unrequited love, she is united with Rochester in a partnership of mutual affection and respect. The story closes with Jane happy in her marriage and surrounded by family, while St. John, steadfast in his religious calling, continues his work abroad.

---

This summary includes the key events, developments, and outcomes for the principal characters as found strictly in your provided text, from Jane’s childhood to her ultimate happiness with Rochester.

## Detailed Plot Summary of "Madame Bovary" (Text Provided)

### Part I

The novel begins with Charles Bovary, a shy, awkward country boy, entering a new school, where he is ridiculed for his rustic background and appearance. He is the son of a retired army surgeon and his embittered, hardworking wife. Charles’s schooling is mediocre, but he eventually studies medicine and, after some academic struggles, becomes a country doctor, largely due to his mother’s persistence.

His first marriage is arranged by his mother to a much older, unattractive, and controlling widow, Heloise Dubuc, who soon dies under suspicious and tragic circumstances, leaving Charles single again.

While treating a wealthy local farmer, Monsieur Rouault, for a broken leg, Charles meets the farmer's well-educated and attractive daughter, Emma. She had been raised in a convent, where her head was filled with romantic and religious fantasies. She finds everyday rural life dull and dreams of passion, luxury, and drama.

Charles and Emma are married after some courtship, but Emma quickly grows bored with her husband’s simple ways and the monotony of village life. She romanticizes love and finds her marriage doesn’t match her literary imaginings. Hoping for excitement, Charles takes Emma to a grand ball at the château of the Marquis d’Andervilliers. The event dazzles Emma, heightening her dissatisfaction with her provincial existence and Charles’s mediocrity.

Back at home, Emma’s discontent grows. She becomes ill, possibly from unhappiness, and Charles, hoping to improve her health, moves his practice to the larger market town of Yonville. Emma is pregnant as they leave Tostes.

### Part II

The Bovarys settle in Yonville. Their circle now includes Monsieur Homais, the town's opinionated pharmacist; the local priest, Bournisien; M. Lheureux, the cunning merchant; and Léon Dupuis, a young, intellectual law clerk who is instantly smitten with Emma. Emma gives birth to a daughter, Berthe, but is disappointed not to have a son. She finds motherhood unfulfilling and grows closer to Léon, who shares her taste for art, music, and literature.

Léon and Emma develop a secret mutual attraction, but both are timid. Unable to confess his love, Léon eventually leaves for Paris to study law, and Emma falls into a state of malaise, her hopes and passions once again frustrated.

Emma’s debts begin to accumulate due to her love of luxury, which Homais and Lheureux encourage. She is courted by Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy, cynical local landowner, who, seeing Emma’s dissatisfaction and romantic fantasies, seduces her. She becomes his mistress, finding, for a time, the passion she longed for.

As her affair with Rodolphe continues, Emma’s extravagance increases, and she neglects her household, her daughter, and Charles. Rodolphe, however, is growing bored. When Emma proposes they run away together, he abandons her at the last moment, leaving her a cold, formulaic letter. Devastated, Emma falls gravely ill, and Charles nurses her back to health.

Recovering, Emma seeks solace in religion, becoming temporarily pious, but the effort does not last. The Bovarys’ financial situation worsens, in part due to Emma’s continued spending and Lheureux’s manipulations. Charles suggests a trip to the opera in Rouen. At the performance, Emma is reunited with Léon, now a more confident and worldly young man.

### Part III

Emma and Léon begin a passionate affair. To meet him, Emma pretends to take weekly piano lessons in Rouen. Their relationship is intense at first but soon grows stale. Emma's demands on Léon for attention and money increase, and the passion drains, leaving both feeling empty and burdened.

Emma’s debts grow out of control. Lheureux cajoles her into signing bills, mortgaging what little property she inherited. When she faces foreclosure and public ruin, she desperately seeks money, first from Léon (who cannot or will not help her), then from several other people, including the notary Guillaumin (who tries to seduce her in return, which she refuses in disgust), and finally, in a last-ditch effort, from her former lover Rodolphe. He, too, refuses.

Penniless and out of options, Emma returns home. In a panic, she tricks Justin, Homais’s young assistant, into opening the chemist’s locked storeroom and consumes arsenic to end her life.

Emma’s death is protracted and agonizing. Charles and others try in vain to save her, but she dies in convulsions, leaving Charles and little Berthe behind. The town is amazed and scandalized by her end.

After her funeral, Charles’s spirit is broken. He gradually discovers her infidelities by reading her preserved letters. Even so, he continues to idolize her memory, neglecting everything else. He eventually dies in abject poverty, sitting in the garden with a lock of Emma’s hair in his hand. Their orphaned daughter Berthe is sent to live with relatives, who eventually put her to work in a cotton mill.

The final pages describe the fate of the remaining characters: the pharmacist Homais prospers and finally receives the cross of the Legion of Honour, while the rest fade to obscurity, crushed beneath the consequences of Emma's reckless pursuit of romance and luxury.

---

**End of Summary.**

summary_llm:
Certainly! Below is a **very detailed, plot-only summary** of the entire storyline of *Mrs. Dalloway* as reflected exclusively in the text you have provided, with all principal events, situations, character actions, and the conclusion, free of interpretation, context, or analysis.

---

### Detailed Plot Summary of *Mrs. Dalloway* (from provided text)

The novel begins on a June morning in London. **Clarissa Dalloway**, a high-society woman, steps outside to buy flowers for the party she will host later that evening. As she moves through the city, her thoughts drift to memories from her youth at Bourton, especially her friendship with **Sally Seton** and her close relationship with **Peter Walsh**, who once asked her to marry him, but whom she refused. While she is out, Clarissa meets her old friend **Hugh Whitbread**, who tells her about his wife Evelyn’s health and discusses plans to attend Clarissa's party.

In parallel, the story introduces **Septimus Warren Smith**, a World War I veteran suffering from psychological trauma, walking with his Italian wife **Lucrezia (Rezia)**. Septimus is troubled by hallucinations and is haunted by the memory of his friend Evans, who died in the war. Passing crowds are excited by a mysterious, important person in a motor car and by an airplane writing advertisements in the sky; Septimus sees meaning and messages in these events, but Rezia is disturbed by his talk and behavior.

Clarissa returns home from her errands and contemplates her life: her marriage, her illness, her friendships, and her identity as Mrs. Dalloway rather than simply Clarissa. She reflects on her relationship with Sally Seton, recalling moments from their youth, including a kiss they shared. She also thinks about Peter Walsh, whom she rejected in favor of Richard Dalloway, and wonders how Peter will find her upon his return from India, which she expects will happen soon.

While mending her green dress, Clarissa is visited unexpectedly by **Peter Walsh**, who has just arrived in London. Their conversation is emotionally intense. Peter reveals he is in love with a married woman named Daisy in India and is seeking a divorce for her. Clarissa and Peter recollect the past, their failed romance, and their friendships at Bourton—a particular incident by a fountain, Clarissa’s relationship with Sally, and Peter’s sense of having been rejected. When Clarissa’s daughter **Elizabeth** enters, Peter quickly leaves, feeling both moved and unsettled.

Outside, Peter wanders the streets of London, reflecting on his past relationship with Clarissa, his experiences in India, and the changes in English society. He observes and follows a young woman for a time, aware of his own impulses and aging, and eventually sits in Regent’s Park, dozing and thinking about the past, especially memories of Bourton: parties, arguments about social issues, Sally’s boldness, and how Clarissa chose Richard.

Meanwhile, Rezia tries to care for Septimus, who grows more disturbed. She despairs at his inability to feel, his madness, and his repeated threats of suicide. Their marriage is tense, and Rezia feels isolated, having left her family in Italy. Septimus’s condition worsens, and Rezia calls for help; Dr. Holmes, their first doctor, dismisses Septimus’s illness, suggesting that there is nothing wrong with him but nerves.

Septimus’s backstory is revealed: his ambitions as a youth, his time in the war, his friendship with Evans (whose death he suppressed emotionally), and his courtship of Rezia after the war in Milan. After the war, he is promoted at work, but his mental state declines. Dr. Holmes continues to insist there is nothing wrong, but as his visions increase and he becomes obsessed with Shakespeare, death, and a sense of persecution, Rezia takes him to see another esteemed doctor: **Sir William Bradshaw**.

Meanwhile, **Richard Dalloway**, Clarissa’s husband, attends lunch at Lady Bruton’s, along with Hugh Whitbread. Lady Bruton asks Richard and Hugh to help her compose a letter to the *Times* about emigration. After lunch, Richard buys Clarissa a large bunch of roses and returns home, intending to tell her he loves her, but fails to say the words. Instead, he settles her for a rest, and leaves for a committee meeting on the Armenians (or Albanians).

Clarissa, now resting, is disturbed by her own feelings of being unfulfilled and ponders the significance of her upcoming party. She feels preoccupied by the idea that Peter and Richard both undervalue her parties and what they represent for her. She is further troubled by her daughter Elizabeth’s close attachment to her history teacher, **Miss Doris Kilman**, a religious and intellectual woman whom Clarissa dislikes intensely. Elizabeth departs with Miss Kilman to go to the Army and Navy Stores. During tea, Elizabeth is uncomfortable with Miss Kilman, who is preoccupied with her own religious suffering and personal grievances.

At the same time, Septimus and Rezia attend their appointment with Sir William Bradshaw, who prescribes complete rest for Septimus in a private home (essentially a mental hospital) and recommends that he and Rezia be separated for his recovery. Sir William’s method is authoritarian and chilling, separating those with nervous breakdowns from their loved ones and surroundings. Rezia feels abandoned and betrayed by the medical profession.

Elizabeth, riding on the top deck of an omnibus, reflects on her own future, considering the professions and city life as she travels through London. She considers becoming a doctor, a farmer, or even entering politics, but ultimately returns home.

Returning to Septimus, he and Rezia experience a brief moment of connection as they work together on a hat for Mrs. Peters. For a short while, Septimus appears happy and at ease, but the prospect of being taken away by Bradshaw looms. When Dr. Holmes comes to take him, Septimus, in a state of fear and a wish to preserve his independence, throws himself out the window and lands fatally on the area railings below. Rezia is left shocked, and Dr. Holmes pronounces it a suicide by sudden impulse.

As evening falls, Clarissa’s party begins. Servants prepare the house, guests arrive, and Clarissa mingles, greeting each with her customary warmth and politeness. Among the guests are Lady Bruton, Hugh Whitbread, Richard, Elizabeth, Ellie Henderson (an awkward cousin), Professor Brierly, Miss Parry (Clarissa’s elderly aunt), and even the Prime Minister, who makes a brief, ceremonial appearance. As the party progresses, Clarissa is surprised by the arrival of Sally Seton (now **Lady Rosseter**), who has not seen her for years and is now married to a Manchester cotton magnate with five sons. Sally and Peter Walsh find themselves talking together in a quiet corner, reminiscing about Bourton and discussing their lives.

Clarissa tries to keep her guests happy, but is suddenly disturbed by the arrival of Sir William and Lady Bradshaw, who bring news—almost as gossip—that one of Sir William’s patients, a young man recently returned from the war (Septimus), has killed himself by jumping out a window. Clarissa is deeply affected by this: she retreats, alone, into a little room. She considers the act of the young man—his death—and feels a sense of kinship, a recognition of the act as a defiance and an attempt to communicate something profound, even as she is absorbed by the social obligations of her party.

She pulls herself together and returns to the party. Peter and Sally, sitting together, are discussing Clarissa—her marriage, Richard, and the choices she has made. Peter still feels strongly about Clarissa and is restless that she is not there with them. At that moment, Clarissa returns, and as Peter sees her, he is filled with extraordinary excitement.

---

**The book ends at this instant**, with Clarissa having rejoined the party, and Peter feeling an intense, wordless emotion at her presence, leaving the moment open and charged as Clarissa stands before him.

---

**Main Events and Key Developments:**
- Clarissa prepares for and hosts her party, reflecting on her life, marriage, and past relationships.
- Peter Walsh returns from India, visits Clarissa, and reveals he’s in love with a married woman.
- Septimus Warren Smith, traumatized by the war, struggles with his mental health and is failed by doctors.
- Septimus’s wife Rezia desperately tries to help him; he ultimately escapes being institutionalized by committing suicide.
- Clarissa’s party brings together friends and family, culminating in the news of Septimus’s death.
- Clarissa is affected by the news and momentarily withdraws, then returns to the party.
- The novel ends with Peter and Sally sitting together, Clarissa rejoining them, and Peter overwhelmed as he sees her.

---

**All major characters and situations are introduced, their storylines interweave throughout this single day, and the events of the day are concluded with the party, Clarissa’s reaction to death, and a final, unresolved emotional moment between Peter and Clarissa.**

**Pride and Prejudice: Detailed Plot Summary**

The story opens at the Bennet family’s home in Longbourn, with Mrs. Bennet excitedly informing her husband that the nearby Netherfield Park has been let to Mr. Bingley, a single, wealthy man. Mrs. Bennet’s main concern is to see one of her five daughters—Jane, Elizabeth (Lizzy), Mary, Catherine (Kitty), and Lydia—married to a rich husband, and she urges Mr. Bennet to visit Mr. Bingley as soon as possible to introduce the girls.

Mr. Bennet, after teasing his wife and daughters, ultimately visits Mr. Bingley. This leads to much speculation and gossip in the Bennet household about prospects for the girls, particularly Jane, the eldest and most beautiful.

At a local assembly (ball), the Bennets meet Mr. Bingley, his two sisters (Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley), Mr. Hurst (the husband of Mrs. Hurst), and Mr. Darcy, Bingley’s rich friend. Bingley is friendly and dances with many ladies, especially Jane, while Darcy’s aloof and proud demeanor offends the local society. Darcy notably refuses to dance with Elizabeth and openly calls her "tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me", which she overhears and which becomes a source of offense and amusement for her and her friends.

Jane and Bingley quickly become mutually attracted. Elizabeth and her friend Charlotte Lucas discuss that Jane ought not conceal her feelings too much, lest Bingley not understand her affection. Meanwhile, Darcy begins to notice Elizabeth’s wit and intelligence, but she remains unaware of any interest on his part.

The Bennet family learns that Bingley’s sisters are polite to Jane, though they look down on her family. The Bingleys and Darcy discuss Jane’s beauty and the inferiority of her family’s status and connections.

A militia regiment arrives in Meryton, and the younger Bennet girls, particularly Lydia and Kitty, are fascinated by the officers. The girls meet the charming Mr. Wickham, who hints at having been mistreated by Darcy, and Elizabeth quickly sides with Wickham.

Jane is invited to dine with the Bingley sisters at Netherfield. Mrs. Bennet sends her on horseback, hoping for rain and that Jane will have to stay overnight, increasing her time with Bingley. Jane falls ill at Netherfield, and Elizabeth, worried for her, walks the three miles through mud to stay with her. Elizabeth’s forthrightness and care for her sister are noticed, and her muddy appearance is criticized by the Bingley sisters but admired by Bingley and even Darcy.

During her stay, Elizabeth observes Darcy's growing attention to her. Darcy, to his own chagrin, finds himself increasingly drawn to Elizabeth. There are various conversations at Netherfield regarding accomplishments, reading, and the differences between Darcy and Bingley. Elizabeth and the rest of the family eventually return home.

Mr. Collins, a pompous and obsequious clergyman, cousin and heir to Mr. Bennet’s estate, writes announcing his visit. Mr. Collins is seeking a wife as advised by his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh. He initially sets his sights on Jane, but when Mrs. Bennet hints Jane may soon be engaged, shifts to Elizabeth.

Mr. Collins arrives and praises the Bennet girls, the house, and especially the grandeur of his patroness. He reads sermons to the family, and is generally insufferable. The girls visit Meryton, meeting Mr. Wickham, who, in conversation with Elizabeth, tells her that Darcy defrauded him of a promised living (church appointment) after his father’s death. Elizabeth accepts Wickham’s tale with little question, deepening her dislike of Darcy.

At a ball at Netherfield, Wickham does not attend, supposedly to avoid Darcy. Elizabeth, disappointed, is forced to dance with Mr. Collins, whose lack of social grace embarrasses her. Darcy asks Elizabeth to dance; she reluctantly accepts, and their conversation is filled with tension about the rumors and their mutual pride.

Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet foolishly boasts about a possible engagement between Jane and Bingley to Lady Lucas, within earshot of Darcy. Mary embarrasses the family by singing poorly; Mr. Collins further exposes the family’s lack of sophistication. Afterwards, Bingley goes to London, and his sisters soon follow, with no clear intention of returning. Jane is heartbroken, and Elizabeth blames Bingley’s sisters and Darcy for his withdrawal.

Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth; she refuses, but he believes her refusal is a female affectation. Her father, brought in, supports Elizabeth. Mr. Collins, after a day or two, proposes instead to Charlotte Lucas, who, wanting security, accepts him—shocking Elizabeth.

Jane is invited to visit her aunt and uncle, the Gardiners, in London. There, Jane tries to see Miss Bingley, who acts coldly, confirming for Jane and Elizabeth that Bingley’s sisters do not wish for her to marry their brother.

Wickham begins to court a wealthy young lady, Miss King, revealing to Elizabeth that he is motivated at least as much by money as affection. Meanwhile, Lydia is invited to Brighton with Mrs. Forster; Elizabeth tries, unsuccessfully, to prevent her from going.

Elizabeth visits her friend Charlotte, now Mrs. Collins, at the parsonage near Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s estate, Rosings Park. She meets Lady Catherine, who is domineering and self-important, and her sickly daughter, Miss de Bourgh, who is intended by Lady Catherine to marry Darcy, her nephew.

During Elizabeth’s stay, Darcy and his cousin Colonel Fitzwilliam arrive at Rosings. Darcy behaves awkwardly, often seeking Elizabeth’s company. Fitzwilliam inadvertently reveals to Elizabeth that Darcy was responsible for separating Bingley and Jane, confirming Elizabeth’s suspicions and angering her.

Then, Darcy abruptly proposes to Elizabeth. He declares his love but also details all the objections to her family and inferior connections. Offended, Elizabeth refuses and castigates him for both separating Jane and Bingley, and wronging Wickham.

The next day, Darcy gives Elizabeth a letter explaining his actions. He says he believed Jane was indifferent to Bingley, and thus persuaded Bingley not to propose. Regarding Wickham, Darcy exposes the truth: Wickham received his inheritance but squandered it, tried to elope with Darcy’s 15-year-old sister for her fortune, and is not the wronged party. Elizabeth is stunned and ashamed, realizing her own prejudice and misjudgment of Darcy and Wickham, and recognizes her family’s improprieties.

Elizabeth returns home, full of new understanding and regret for her earlier behavior and judgments. The militia leaves Meryton; Lydia is invited to Brighton, despite Elizabeth’s warnings about her irresponsibility.

Elizabeth accompanies the Gardiners on a trip to Derbyshire, where they plan to visit the Lakes, but alter their route and visit Pemberley, Darcy’s estate, when assured by the housekeeper that Darcy is not at home. The housekeeper praises Darcy’s character, contradicting Elizabeth’s old view of him. While touring the grounds, Darcy himself appears unexpectedly. To Elizabeth’s surprise, Darcy is extremely polite and attentive to her and her relatives.

Darcy introduces Elizabeth to his sister Georgiana at Pemberley. Bingley visits, and is kind and friendly to Elizabeth and her relatives. Darcy’s changed, respectful behavior makes a strong impression on Elizabeth.

Then, Elizabeth receives urgent letters from Jane: Lydia has run away with Wickham, and it is believed they are not married. The family is thrown into chaos and disgrace. Elizabeth rushes home with her aunt and uncle. Her father, after searching in London, returns home without Lydia, deeply grieved. It is revealed that Mr. Gardiner finds Lydia and Wickham, and Wickham agrees to marry Lydia if his debts are paid and he receives a modest income. The family believes it is Mr. Gardiner’s financial support that persuaded Wickham, but Elizabeth suspects Darcy’s hand.

Lydia and Wickham return as man and wife, unashamed. Lydia lets slip to Elizabeth that Darcy was present at her wedding. Elizabeth writes to Mrs. Gardiner, who confirms Darcy found the couple, paid Wickham’s debts, provided the marriage settlement, and kept everything secret—out of love for Elizabeth.

Bingley, encouraged by Darcy, returns to Netherfield, visits the Bennets, and soon proposes to Jane, who joyfully accepts. Lady Catherine de Bourgh appears at Longbourn, furious at rumors that Darcy intends to marry Elizabeth, and demands Elizabeth promise not to marry him. Elizabeth refuses. Lady Catherine reports this defiance to Darcy, which encourages him that Elizabeth may now accept him.

Darcy returns to Longbourn, and he and Elizabeth finally confess their love and become engaged. Mr. Bennet is initially surprised but, once assured of their genuine affection, gives his consent. Mrs. Bennet is overjoyed by the prospect of such rich and noble sons-in-law.

Bingley and Jane marry and move nearby. Darcy and Elizabeth marry and live at Pemberley. Lydia and Wickham’s marriage is troubled and financially strained; they often ask their sisters for help. Kitty spends much time with Jane and Elizabeth, improving in character. Mary remains at home with her parents. Lady Catherine, after an initial period of anger, is reconciled to Darcy and Elizabeth. The Gardiners remain close to the Darcys, forever cherished for their kindness.

Thus, the story ends with two of the Bennet sisters happily settled, their parents content, and the family’s fortunes much improved by the marriages of Jane to Bingley and Elizabeth to Darcy.

---

**Key developments and events (chronologically):**
- Mr. Bingley, a wealthy bachelor, moves to Netherfield; the Bennet family seeks a match for their daughters.
- Mrs. Bennet is marriage-obsessed, especially for her eldest daughter Jane.
- At a ball, Mr. Bingley is drawn to Jane; Mr. Darcy offends Elizabeth.
- Jane and Bingley grow close; Darcy notices Elizabeth’s charm.
- Mr. Collins, the family’s heir, proposes to Elizabeth (after being dissuaded from Jane); Elizabeth refuses.
- Elizabeth befriends Wickham, who claims Darcy wronged him.
- At a ball, Darcy asks Elizabeth to dance; tension ensues.
- Bingley leaves for London; Jane is heartbroken, Elizabeth blames Darcy and Bingley’s sisters.
- Charlotte accepts Mr. Collins’ proposal.
- Elizabeth visits Charlotte, meets Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and then Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam.
- Fitzwilliam reveals Darcy’s role in separating Bingley and Jane.
- Darcy proposes to Elizabeth; she refuses and berates him.
- Darcy writes Elizabeth a letter explaining his actions and reveals Wickham’s villainy.
- Lydia elopes with Wickham; family is disgraced.
- Darcy locates Lydia and Wickham and arranges their marriage.
- Bingley returns and proposes to Jane.
- Lady Catherine tries to dissuade Elizabeth from marrying Darcy; Elizabeth refuses.
- Darcy proposes again; Elizabeth accepts.
- Double wedding: Jane/Bingley and Elizabeth/Darcy.
- Lydia and Wickham’s marriage is troubled; Kitty improves away from Lydia’s influence; Mary remains at home.
- Lady Catherine is eventually reconciled to the Darcys.
- The story concludes with happiness and prosperity for the main characters.

---

**Conclusion:**  
Elizabeth and Darcy’s mutual recognition of pride and prejudice in themselves leads to their understanding and union. Jane and Bingley’s affection is similarly fulfilled. Lydia’s reckless behavior is counter-balanced by Darcy’s intervention, saving the family’s reputation. The Bennet family, after numerous trials and humiliations, ultimately sees two of its daughters happily and advantageously married, securing their future happiness.

---

This summary covers each character’s situation and trajectory, the sequence and cause of all key events, major social gatherings and proposals, misunderstandings, the crucial revelations and letters, dramatic turns like Lydia’s elopement, and the various marriages that resolve the storyline.

summary_llm:
Certainly! Here is an extremely detailed summary of the plot of the provided text of "The Life and Adventures of Robinson Crusoe," strictly based only on the text and following your instructions for comprehensiveness and key developments:

---

**Robinson Crusoe’s Early Life and First Voyages**

Robinson Crusoe, born 1632 in York to a merchant family of foreign descent, is the youngest of three sons. His father wishes him to pursue a stable, middle-class life, but Robinson is driven by a restless desire to see the world. Disregarding his father’s tearful warnings and predictions of misery, and ignoring his mother's pleading, Crusoe eventually leaves home at age 18, boarding a ship at Hull bound for London without his parents’ knowledge or blessing.

His very first seafaring adventure is marked by disaster: the ship is battered by storms, and Crusoe, frightened and seasick, vows to return home should he survive. However, as soon as the weather improves and he is persuaded by his sailor companions, he forgets his resolutions and boards another vessel, eventually reaching London.

In London, Crusoe connects with the captain of a Guinea trading ship, who recruits him as a companion for a trading voyage to Africa. This journey proves successful, and Crusoe profits considerably. Encouraged by this gain, he attempts another voyage with a new captain. This time, disaster strikes: the ship is attacked by a Moorish pirate. Crusoe and the crew are captured and taken into slavery in Sallee, a port of the Moors.

**Slavery and Escape**

Crusoe becomes the personal slave of the pirate captain. Although well-treated, he longs for escape. After two years, he seizes an opportunity when sent out fishing with a boy named Xury and a Moor. Crusoe throws the Moor overboard, threatens him with a gun, and gains Xury’s loyal assistance. Together, Crusoe and Xury travel down the African coast, suffering hardships and repeatedly evading wild animals and possible hostile natives.

After a perilous journey, they are rescued by a Portuguese ship bound for Brazil. The captain is generous, purchasing Xury’s service and all of Robinson’s goods, delivering Crusoe to Brazil, where he is well cared for and eventually settles as a planter.

**Life as a Planter and the Fateful Expedition**

Crusoe prospers in Brazil, acquiring land and slaves, but becomes restless again. In pursuit of greater fortune, he joins a trading expedition to Guinea to buy slaves, leaving trusted friends in charge of his plantation. During the voyage, a fierce storm arises and the ship is blown off course, beyond the Caribbean, eventually wrecked upon an unknown island.

**Shipwreck and Arrival on the Island**

Crusoe is the sole survivor of the wreck. Struggling ashore with nothing but the clothes on his back, he spends a terrified night in a tree, fearing wild beasts. Upon discovering the beached but intact ship, he salvages as many supplies as he can—food, tools, weapons, powder, clothing, and various other items. He constructs a makeshift shelter using sails and salvaged wood, and gradually builds a fortified dwelling, digging out a cave in the rock at the rear for storage and security.

He keeps a journal, marking time by notching a large cross. Crusoe survives on salvaged ship’s provisions, then gradually learns to hunt, fish, and gather fruits and berries. He discovers wild goats, which he shoots for food and tries to domesticate. He experiences loneliness, isolation, terror, and guilt, especially after experiencing storms and sickness, which leads to a religious awakening and repentance.

**Survival and Self-Reliance**

Crusoe spends years adapting to island life. He devises means to create pottery by trial and error, learns to make primitive tools, baskets, and eventually builds furniture. He finds some barley and rice sprouting from discarded chicken feed and carefully cultivates it, learning through trial and error how to sow and harvest crops, and eventually is able to bake bread. He also builds fences and enclosures to domesticate goats for milk, meat, and hides, and soon has a reliable food source and learns to make cheese and butter.

He creates a second, more rural retreat deeper inland (the Bower), enabling him to range further for hunting and collecting fruits and raisins.

**Encounters with Cannibals and the Arrival of Friday**

After many years alone, Crusoe sees a footprint in the sand, which fills him with terror, as it means his island is not uninhabited. He struggles with paranoia and fear, eventually discovering evidence of cannibal feasts (remains of eaten humans) on the island’s shore. He builds further defenses for his dwelling, camouflaging and fortifying it.

One day, Crusoe observes a group of cannibals landing on the shore with prisoners. One of the prisoners escapes, pursued by his captors, and Crusoe saves him, shooting two pursuers and helping the man, whom he names Friday (after the day of the rescue). Crusoe feeds and clothes Friday, and the two become companions. Friday gratefully becomes Crusoe’s loyal servant and pupil, learning English and European ways, and eventually converts to Christianity.

From Friday, Crusoe learns about the mainland, the customs of Friday’s people (including the practice of cannibalism), and that there are other Europeans (white, bearded men) living on the mainland after their shipwreck.

**Saving Friday’s Father and the Spaniard**

Later, a group of cannibals arrives with more prisoners. Crusoe and Friday attack, killing many and rescuing two men—one of whom is Friday’s father, and the other a Spaniard. Crusoe welcomes them, shelters and feeds them, and learns the Spaniard is one of several survivors from a Spanish shipwreck living on the mainland. Together they hatch a plan to eventually bring over the rest of the Spaniards to the island and escape together.

However, Crusoe is cautious, not wishing to risk being overrun, and insists on careful planning, ensuring there will be enough food for all.

**The Mutiny and Rescue**

Before the Spaniards can return, Crusoe and his companions discover an English ship has landed, with a longboat and prisoners coming ashore. Crusoe discovers, via conversation, that the captain and some loyal crew members have been overpowered by mutineers and set ashore. The rest are wandering the island or guarding the ship.

Crusoe allies with the captain and they carefully overpower the mutineers, taking some prisoner and winning others to their cause. With careful planning and deception, they retake the ship by night, killing and capturing the mutinous leaders, and sending false signals to the ship so as to lure more back to shore, whom they also capture.

Crusoe emerges as the ‘governor’ of the island, dictating terms. He spares the remaining mutineers on condition they stay behind on the island rather than face the hangman in England, gives them provisions, arms, and instructions for agriculture and survival, and arranges for the rescue of the Spanish castaways (leaving a letter for them).

**Return to England**

Crusoe, Friday, the captain, and the loyal English crew board the recovered ship and sail to England. They arrive after a long absence; Crusoe’s parents are dead, but he finds sisters and distant relations, and is eventually able to recover some of his old assets from loyal friends and from his years of agricultural labor in Brazil.

He seeks and finds news of his long-abandoned Brazilian plantation and, via letters and legal channels, is able to claim his share, making him wealthy. He travels to Lisbon and communicates with his Brazilian partner, arranging the sale of his share and repaying acts of kindness from others, particularly the Portuguese captain who had rescued him from Africa.

**Further Travels, Adventures, and Reflections**

Despite his newfound wealth and security, Crusoe is restless and eventually returns to England, where he marries, has children, and later, after his wife’s death and the successful voyages of a nephew, is persuaded to undertake another voyage as a private trader to the East Indies.

Before this, Crusoe visits his old island, finding the Spaniards who had been left, learning the history of their survival, their battles with Caribs, their internal disputes, and the eventual peaceful and prosperous settlement of the island, now populated with men and women and well-stocked with livestock and crops.

Crusoe divides the land among them, provides supplies and tools, and ensures their continued prosperity. He departs, arranging for further settlers and animals to be sent later from Brazil, and leaves an account for the Second Part of his adventures.

---

**Key Developments, Events, and Storyline Flow**

- Crusoe’s defiance of his parents and desire to travel;
- Early misadventures at sea and repeated warnings in the form of hardship and disasters;
- Success and then disaster in the Guinea trade, leading to slave captivity;
- Dramatic escape from slavery (with Xury), perilous journey along the African coast, and rescue by a Portuguese ship;
- Prosperity as a sugar planter in Brazil, then restlessness and joining a fateful slaving expedition;
- The shipwreck that maroons Crusoe on a deserted island;
- Survival by salvaging the ship, constructing shelter, learning agriculture, domesticating animals, and inventing tools;
- Severe loneliness, spiritual struggle, and gradual religious conversion;
- Sighting of cannibal activity on the island and years of anxious and hostile readiness;
- Rescue and friendship with Friday, efforts to educate and civilize him, and conversion to Christianity;
- Rescue of other prisoners, including Friday’s father and a Spaniard, learning of other European castaways;
- Arrival of an English ship with mutineers, alliance with the captain, retaking of the ship through strategy and combat;
- Clemency or banishment for the defeated mutineers; arrangements for the settlement and survival of those left behind;
- Triumphant departure from the island after 28 years, return to England, reacquisition of wealth, and efforts to repay old kindnesses;
- Crusoe’s restlessness, new marriage, children, and eventual return to adventure and his island, where he finds it thriving;
- His parting arrangements and promises of a further account in a second part to his life.

**Conclusion**

The novel closes with Crusoe wealthy, at peace with his adventures, yet still restless and drawn to new journeys, leaving open the prospect of more tales to come.

---

This summary strictly follows the events and storyline as described in the provided text, presenting all the main plot developments, characters’ actions, and the sequence of key situations, from Crusoe’s early life through to his eventual rescue, return, and subsequent ventures. No analysis, context, or outside knowledge has been included, only the narrative details as rendered in the full text you gave.

book_title: Six Characters in Search of an Author-Luigi Pirandello
summary_llm:
Certainly! Below is a **very detailed plot summary** of the play *Six Characters in Search of an Author* based entirely and ONLY on the text provided above, with all major events, situations, character developments, and the conclusion, in careful detail.

---

## Plot Summary

### Introduction and Setting

The play opens on a half-lit, empty stage intended to give the audience an impression of spontaneity. The actors and actresses of a theatre company enter to rehearse a Pirandello play called *Mixing It Up*. The Manager, his Secretary, the Prompter, and the Property Man are present. The Manager gives instructions as rehearsal is about to begin.

### The Six Characters Arrive

Suddenly, a group enters: **Six Characters**. They have a strange, radiant presence and are comprised of:

- **The Father**: About 50, alternately smooth and violent.
- **The Mother**: Crushed, veiled, wax-like, eyes downcast.
- **The Step-Daughter**: Bold, beautiful, dressed in elegant mourning, scornful of the Boy, loving to the Child.
- **The Son**: 22, tall, cold, contemptuous towards the Father and indifferent to the Mother.
- **The Boy**: 14, timid, dressed in black.
- **The Child**: About 4, in white with a black sash.

The doorman tries to announce them, but the Characters present themselves directly, claiming they are “in search of an author.”

### Explanation and Plea of the Six Characters

**The Father** explains they are **unfinished characters** abandoned by their author before he could put them in a play. They are alive, carrying a powerful, unresolved drama. They plead with the Manager to be allowed to “live” their story, to be given form through acting.

**The Manager** and actors at first think it’s a joke or madness, but the Characters insist on the truth and vividness of their tragedy. The Step-Daughter, in particular, urges that their drama be staged, even breaking out into song and dance to show her contrasting emotions.

### Revelation of the Family Drama

Under the Manager’s questioning, the nature of their drama unfolds:

- The **Father** was once married to the **Mother**, but feeling her a “poor insignificant woman” and recognizing her closeness to his secretary, he intentionally sends her away to be with the secretary, hoping to free both himself and her. She takes their legitimate son (**The Son**) too, but the Father arranges for the Son to be reared elsewhere.
- The Mother and the secretary have three children (**The Step-Daughter, Boy, and Child**). The secretary dies, leaving the family destitute. They return to the city but do not contact the Father.
- The Mother, forced by poverty, becomes a modiste at Madame Pace’s shop, an establishment that secretly doubles as a front for a brothel.
- The Step-Daughter, older now, falls into Madame Pace’s “web.” The Father, seeking female comfort, becomes a client of the shop and by sheer chance is united with the Step-Daughter in a compromising, near-incestuous situation. The Mother interrupts the encounter before anything irreparable happens, and the family is reunited under the Father's roof.
- The Step-Daughter feels shame and revenge, The Mother feels torment, guilt and grief, The Son is detached and scornful, and The Boy is deeply withdrawn.

### The Manager's Interest and Attempt to Stage the Drama

The Manager becomes intrigued and proposes to stage their story. The Characters and the actors clash over **authenticity**: the Characters insist only they can fully be themselves, while the Manager and actors maintain that it is the job of actors to bring characters to life.

The Characters begin to **enact scenes from their drama** directly, showing their raw emotions and conflicts—especially the tragic situation at Madame Pace’s. The Step-Daughter and Father act out their near-encounter in the shop, with the Mother in agony as she watches.

The Manager tries to have the actors imitate the Characters, but this only makes the Characters frustrated, as the actors’ performances do not capture the reality and emotion of their experiences. The Step-Daughter and Father laugh or protest at how poorly their roles are being performed.

### Rehearsal, Reality, and Escalating Tension

There is **conflict between acting and being**. The Step-Daughter insists that her horror and humiliation be shown as it truly was, not softened or sentimentalized for the stage. The Manager counters that some things are too raw for an audience.

The Son expresses his alienation, insisting he does not belong to this drama and refusing to participate, but is compelled to remain by his bond to the family’s tragic fate.

The Father attempts to defend his behavior, explaining his motives and how circumstances led to the regrettable events. The Step-Daughter and the other family members reject or challenge his explanations, each insisting on their separate truth.

### The Final Scene: Catastrophe in the Garden

As the Manager tries to shape the drama into a “playable” form, he groups the action in a garden setting. The Step-Daughter notes, however, that not everything can be shown this way: for example, the Boy’s suffering and the Son’s isolation are internal and not easily staged.

The Son, in defiance, claims he will not act and tries to leave, but is unable to. The Step-Daughter mocks his inability to escape the drama.

**A climactic tragedy unfolds:**
- The Boy drifts, silent and sad, in the background.
- The little Child plays by a fountain.
- The Mother moves to connect with her son, the Son, but he rejects her and leaves.
- Suddenly, the Child is seen to have drowned in the fountain while the Mother was distracted.
- The Boy, having witnessed his little sister’s drowning, is overcome with despair and shoots himself (offstage, with a revolver).

There is panic, confusion, and chaos on stage. The Mother screams for help, and the actors scramble to see if the deaths are real.

### Conclusion

In the aftermath, some actors claim it is all "only make believe" or "pretence," while the Father cries out that it is **reality**. The Manager, exasperated and bewildered by not being able to tell what is real and what is illusion, exclaims: “Pretence? Reality? To hell with it all! Never in my life has such a thing happened to me. I’ve lost a whole day over these people, a whole day!”

**Curtain.**

---

**In summary**, the plot follows a theatre company as its routine is upended by the appearance of six unfinished characters, desperate to have their tragic story told. Their drama—of abandonment, shame, failed family, poverty, and near-incest—is rehearsed and relived in front of the skeptical, sometimes mocking, sometimes awed actors, culminating in an unstageable double tragedy that blurs the boundaries of reality and fiction, leaving everyone uncertain as to what is real. The play ends in confusion, frustration, and catastrophe.

book_title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn-Mark Twain
summary_llm:
Certainly! Here is a **very detailed summary** of the plot of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," based **exclusively** on the full text you provided, detailing all main events, situations, developments with characters, and the conclusion, without any outside information, analysis, or context.

---

### Detailed Plot Summary

**The book is narrated by Huckleberry Finn ("Huck"), who recounts events after those of "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer."** At the start, Huck lives with the Widow Douglas, who, along with her sister Miss Watson, tries to "sivilize" him — teaching him manners, religion, and schooling. Huck finds their way of life confining and prefers freedom.

At night, Huck sneaks out with his friend Tom Sawyer to join a spy-themed gang, pretending at robberies and adventures. Their play is imaginative but ultimately amounts to nothing real; after a while, the group loses interest.

Huck’s troubles escalate when his abusive, alcoholic father (Pap) reappears, wanting Huck’s money (part of a fortune found previously). Pap takes Huck away, locking him in a cabin. Huck manages to escape by faking his own murder, using an elaborate plan involving animal blood and leaving misleading clues. He flees to Jackson’s Island in the middle of the river.

There, Huck encounters Jim, Miss Watson’s enslaved man, who has run away fearing he would be sold down south. Huck and Jim team up, and a close friendship develops. While they hide, townsfolk search for Huck’s body, believing he is dead, and suspect Jim of murder.

**Early Adventures on the River:**
- After waiting out a rainstorm and scavenging an abandoned houseboat (where they find a dead body), Huck and Jim acquire supplies and information from the nearby town (Huck goes disguised as a girl to gather news).
- Jim is revealed to be the runaway the townsfolk are hunting, with a reward on his head. Huck and Jim quickly leave Jackson’s Island on a raft they acquire.
- Their plan is to go down the Mississippi River, aiming to reach the Ohio River at Cairo, from where Jim can travel north to freedom.

**The Raft Journey:**
- Huck and Jim float downriver at night and by day hide in the woods on the Illinois side, avoiding detection.
- They face challenges such as fog and separation (Huck is lost from the raft in the fog; Jim is deeply affected, thinking he has lost Huck).
- Huck struggles with his conscience over helping Jim; he has been taught to believe helping an enslaved man escape is immoral, but his growing friendship and respect for Jim make him question this.
- They miss Cairo due to fog and high water, ending up deeper into slave territory, south of where they planned.

**Adventures with Con Artists:**
- Huck and Jim pick up two white men escaping a mob, who claim to be a Duke and a King—frauds who quickly take over and conspire to use Jim as a captive and the raft as their transport.
- The “Duke” and “King” scam multiple towns—putting on fake Shakespeare shows, swindling churchgoers, and eventually concocting the “Royal Nonesuch” con (charging high admission for a lewd, very short act, then escaping before the angry crowd can retaliate).
- They also pretend to be the long-lost brothers of the recently-deceased Peter Wilks, aiming to inherit his fortune by tricking the orphaned nieces.

**Wilks Family Episode:**
- The con men are warmly welcomed by the Wilks nieces and townsfolk as the supposed English brothers. The real brothers arrive, and a complex series of accusations, handwriting tests, and body exhumation ensue.
- Huck, feeling guilty about the con, tries to help the nieces by hiding the stolen money in Peter Wilks’s coffin (which is then accidentally buried).
- During the confrontation at the graveyard, Huck uses the chaos to escape. He returns to the raft, only to find Jim has been captured and sold by the King for a reward.

**Jim’s Capture and the Phelps Farm:**
- Huck searches for Jim, discovering he is being held at the Phelps farm—Tom Sawyer’s aunt and uncle.
- On the way there, Huck bumps into Tom Sawyer himself, who has just arrived by steamboat. Huck tells Tom the situation, and Tom is excited to help with Jim’s rescue.
- Tom pretends to be his own brother, Sid, so they can stay at the Phelps’s without suspicion, and the two devise an elaborate plan to free Jim.

**The Escape Plot:**
- Tom insists on turning the rescue into a dramatic adventure, adding unnecessary complications (digging a tunnel, sending mysterious notes, making a rope ladder baked in a pie, raising rats/snakes/spiders for Jim's “prison”).
- They succeed in sneaking in and out of Jim’s cabin; Aunt Sally grows increasingly frantic as household items disappear (for use in the escape plan).
- Eventually, they execute their escape: they break Jim out at night, but Tom is shot in the calf during the chase.

**Aftermath and Conclusion:**
- Jim risks his freedom to help Tom after he is shot; Huck fetches a doctor to treat Tom, while Jim is recaptured and held in chains again.
- Once the doctor, Phelps family, and townsfolk all gather, the true identities are revealed: Tom admits he knew Jim was free the whole time — Miss Watson had died and freed him in her will.
- Jim is released. The King and the Duke met their comeuppance earlier (tarred and feathered by a mob).
- Tom makes amends to Jim (giving him $40 for his troubles), and the Phelpses offer to adopt and “sivilize” Huck. Huck contemplates going out west ("lighting out for the Territory") to avoid being “sivilized.”

---

**Character Endings:**
- **Huck**: Plans to leave for the west, having had enough of “sivilizing.”
- **Jim**: Is granted his freedom; he was free all along due to Miss Watson’s will, and also reveals to Huck that the dead man they found earlier was Huck's Pap.
- **Tom**: Recovers from his wound; proud of his adventure, he intended all along for Jim to be free.
- The **King and Duke**: Are punished by a mob, tarred and feathered.

---

**The story ends with Huck desiring to escape “sivilizing” influences once and for all, and Jim enjoying his hard-won freedom.** The book closes Huck’s tale and his adventures with Jim along the Mississippi River.

book_title: The Count of Monte Cristo-Alexandre Dumas
summary_llm:
Certainly! Here is a very detailed summary of the complete plot from the provided text, covering all main events, characters, situations, and key developments, including the conclusion—*using only the information given in the text provided above.*

---

### **The Count of Monte Cristo — Detailed Plot Summary**

#### **Part One: Betrayal and Imprisonment**

**Arrival in Marseilles**

The story opens in 1815, when the ship *Pharaon* returns to Marseilles. The young first mate, Edmond Dantès, is warmly greeted by his employer, M. Morrel, who learns that Captain Leclere has died, and that, on his deathbed, Leclere entrusted Dantès with a letter to Marshal Bertrand at the island of Elba. Dantès fulfills this duty and visits the island, where he also meets the exiled Emperor Napoleon, who gives him a letter to deliver in Paris. Dantès is humble, capable, and beloved by the crew, but his success and virtue provoke jealousy in others: Danglars, the ship’s supercargo, who aspires to the captaincy, and Fernand, a Catalan fisherman who is in love with Dantès’ fiancée, Mercédès.

**Conspiracy, Arrest, and Incarceration**

Danglars and Fernand plot against Edmond, drafting an anonymous letter accusing him of being a Bonapartist agent. Caderousse, Dantès’ neighbor, drunkenly witnesses but does not stop this. On the day of Dantès and Mercédès’ wedding, the authorities arrest Dantès based on the anonymous accusation. Dantès is questioned by Villefort, the deputy crown prosecutor. Although Villefort realizes that Dantès is innocent, he discovers the letter from Napoleon is addressed to Villefort's own Bonapartist father. Fearing for his own career, Villefort burns the letter and, to protect himself, condemns Dantès to imprisonment in the Château d’If.

**Despair and Hope in Prison**

Imprisoned for years, Dantès becomes desperate, but after a period of despair, he discovers he has a neighbor. He meets Abbé Faria, a fellow prisoner, through a secret tunnel. Faria educates Edmond in various subjects, and shares his plan for escape, as well as the secret of a massive treasure hidden by Cardinal Spada on the island of Monte Cristo. Faria eventually dies, and Edmond hides in the sack meant for the abbé’s corpse, escaping when he is thrown into the sea.

**Edmond’s Rebirth**

Edmond finds the treasure, becomes fabulously wealthy, and begins to construct a new identity as the mysterious Count of Monte Cristo. He befriends smugglers and learns the ways of the world. With his new wealth, knowledge, and connections, he sets out to pursue vengeance against those who betrayed him: Danglars, Fernand, and Villefort.

---

#### **Part Two: Revenge and Return**

**Monte Cristo’s Arrival in Paris and New Identities**

Dantès, now the Count of Monte Cristo, arrives in Paris, where his dazzling fortune, enigmatic character, and generosity arouse both admiration and suspicion. He acquires various luxurious residences, including a house in the Champs-Élysées and a country estate at Auteuil. He meets and begins to manipulate the families and fortunes of his enemies, assuming additional identities as Lord Wilmore and Abbé Busoni as needed to advance his plans.

**The Fate of Danglars**

Danglars is now a wealthy banker, married, with a daughter, Eugénie. Monte Cristo ruins him financially through a series of intrigues, including manipulating the stock market and encouraging Danglars’ reckless investments. Danglars arranges for his daughter to marry “Andrea Cavalcanti,” who is actually Benedetto, a criminal supported by Monte Cristo. Eventually, Danglars’ fortune is destroyed, and he flees Paris, only to fall into the hands of the bandit Luigi Vampa, who, as part of Monte Cristo’s plan, ransoms him of all his remaining wealth before setting him free, broken and impoverished.

**The Fate of Fernand (de Morcerf)**

Fernand Mondego has risen to become the Count de Morcerf, a peer of France, and is married to Mercédès, with a son named Albert. Monte Cristo arranges for Fernand’s crimes—his betrayal of Ali Pasha of Yanina, and the sale into slavery of Ali’s wife and daughter Haydée—to be exposed in Paris. Haydée, now under Monte Cristo’s protection, testifies against him. Morcerf is disgraced in public and later commits suicide. Mercédès, after receiving consolation and aid from Monte Cristo (who reveals himself as Edmond), chooses a life of seclusion, and Albert, renouncing his name and wealth, decides to rebuild his honor as an officer and leaves for Africa.

**The Fate of Villefort**

Villefort is now the king’s attorney, married to his second wife Héloïse, with a daughter, Valentine, from his first marriage and a young son, Edward, from his second. Monte Cristo purchases a house at Auteuil, where Villefort had once buried his illegitimate child—a crime now brought to light through the trial of Andrea/Benedetto (revealed as his son). Villefort’s household is destroyed by a series of poisonings: first the Saint-Mérans (Valentine’s grandparents), then Barrois the servant, and finally, Valentine herself appears to die. The culprit is revealed to be Villefort’s wife, Héloïse, who was poisoning members of the family to secure her son’s inheritance. Villefort, in a rage, orders her to commit suicide, which she does, but not before poisoning her own child, Edward, as well. Villefort is left alone, his crimes exposed, his mind destroyed.

**Valentine and Morrel**

Valentine, Villefort’s daughter, is in love with Maximilian Morrel, the son of Edmond’s former benefactor, but is being forced into a marriage for political and financial reasons. Monte Cristo intervenes and, knowing of the poison plot, gives her an antidote that saves her from death, allowing her to reunite with Maximilian. The couple is able to escape together, blessed by Noirtier, Valentine’s grandfather.

**Redemption and Mercy**

Monte Cristo, in the course of his revenge, witnesses the suffering caused by the destruction of his enemies’ families—especially the innocent. Reunited with Mercédès, and seeing the pain of Maximilian Morrel, he begins to doubt the justice of absolute vengeance. He saves Valentine, keeps his promise to Morrel not to let him die of grief, and arranges for the happiness of those who remained virtuous and loyal. He gives Morrel and Valentine the fortune from Monte Cristo and entrusts their future to them.

---

#### **Conclusion: Resolution and Departure**

Monte Cristo is finally reunited with Haydée, who loves him, and chooses to remain with her rather than leave the world. He reflects on the lessons of his journey: suffering, mercy, and hope. He rewards all those who were good, punishes the wicked, then departs with Haydée to begin a new life.

Morrel and Valentine, after their trials, are united and gifted a fortune by Monte Cristo, who sends a letter bidding them happiness and leaving them with the maxim that sums up all wisdom: "Wait and hope." Monte Cristo leaves the stage, his vengeance complete, his soul at peace—having finally learned to forgive himself and others.

— *End of Summary*

summary_llm:
Certainly! Here is a **detailed plot summary** of the narrative as provided, focusing exclusively on the events, characters, and storyline as found in the text, encompassing all ten days, their framing story, and the stories told by each character, as well as the conclusion.

---

**The Decameron – Plot Summary**

**Introduction/Framing Narrative:**
The story begins in Florence during the year 1348, when the city is ravaged by the Black Death. Amidst the horror, seven young women, led by Pampinea, gather in a church and, after some discussion, decide to flee the city to escape the plague. They agree to invite three young men whom they encounter at the church, making a company of ten. The group decides to take refuge in the countryside for two weeks, living together in a villa and spending their time in ease and pleasure, shielded from the horrors of the city.

Each day (except for Fridays and Saturdays, which are set aside for religious observances), they elect a king or queen to govern the day's activities. The ruler of the day chooses the theme for the stories that each member must tell. Each day, after their meals and other amusements, the group assembles and each tells a story, resulting in ten stories per day. The narrative includes the lives and interactions of the group between these storytelling sessions.

---

**Day 1:** *Topic: Any subject the storyteller desires*

The group tells stories of fortune, wit, and trickery. These include Master Ciappelletto, who cons a holy friar with a false deathbed confession and is venerated as a saint; Abraham the Jew, who visits Rome to see the Christian faith and, despite seeing much corruption, converts; Melchizedek the Jew escaping Saladin’s trap by using the tale of the three rings; a monk who escapes punishment by cleverly exposing the Abbot’s similar sin; the Marchioness of Monferrato warding off the King of France by serving a dinner of hens; a witty layman shaming a friar’s hypocrisy; Bergamino rebukes the parsimony of Messer Cane; Guglielmo Borsiere corrects the avarice of Ermino Grimaldi; a Gascon lady inspires the King of Cyprus to act nobly; and Master Alberto shames a lady who mocked his love for her.

---

**Day 2:** *Topic: Those who after misfortune achieve an unexpected happy outcome*

Notable tales include Martellino, who fakes a miracle at Saint Arrigo’s tomb and nearly gets lynched; Rinaldo d’Asti, robbed but sheltered by a widow and restored to fortune; three young men lose their inheritance but one marries the disguised daughter of the English king, restoring the whole family; Landolfo Ruffolo, ruined then rescued by a chest of jewels; Andreuccio of Perugia, victim of a string of misadventures in Naples but returns home with a great ruby; Madam Beritola, who, after separation, is reunited with her sons and husband who have all risen to fortune; Alatiel, a Saracen princess who, after many misadventures and passing through several lovers, is restored as a virgin bride; the Count of Antwerp, falsely accused, goes into exile, his children are lost and later found, then his innocence is proven and all are restored; Bernabo, fooled by Ambrogiuolo into believing his wife Ginevra unfaithful, orders her slain, but she survives, becomes famous, and finally exposes the truth, reuniting with her husband; and Paganino of Monaco who abducts the wife of Messer Ricciardo, she chooses Paganino over her jealous husband.

---

**Day 3:** *Topic: People who achieved desired things or recovered lost things through ingenuity*

Tales are told of Masetto da Lamporecchio, who feigns being mute to become the gardener at a convent, is seduced by all the nuns and the abbess, and is rewarded; a monk avoids punishment by shifting blame onto his abbot; a woman secures an assignation with her lover with the help of a clever friar; Dom Felice helps his friend perform a penance, then beds his wife while he does it; a clever palfrey secured by Ricciardo Zima by tricking a Pistoiese noble’s wife into revealing her desire; Ricciardo Minutolo tricks Catella into sleeping with him by exploiting her jealousy; Tedaldo Elisei returns to Florence in disguise after being presumed dead and saves his former lover’s husband from execution; Ferondo is tricked by the abbot into thinking he is dead and in purgatory while the abbot beds his wife; Gillette of Narbonne cures the French king and tricks Bertrand into marrying her, eventually winning his love; and Alibech learns to "put the devil in hell" from the hermit Rustico, i.e., discovers sexual pleasure.

---

**Day 4:** *Topic: Unhappy love stories*

These include the tragedy of Ghismonda and Guiscardo, punished by Tancred; Fra Alberto, who, as the “Angel Gabriel,” is exposed and humiliated; three pairs of lovers meet grim fates due to jealousy and violence; Gerbino, who tries to rescue his beloved from a ship and both die; Lisabetta buries her lover’s head in a pot of basil and dies of grief; Andrevuola loses her lover and, after misadventures, becomes a nun; Simona and Pasquino both die from poisonous sage; Girolamo and Salvestra, whose love ends with both dead; Sir Guillaume de Roussillon makes his wife eat her lover’s heart and she kills herself; and a physician’s wife’s lover is discovered in a stolen chest, but all escape worse fates through quick thinking.

---

**Day 5:** *Topic: Lovers who suffered adversity but attained happiness*

Cimon, once a boor, becomes wise and wins Iphigenia; Costanza, believing Martuccio dead, is driven by fate to North Africa, and after many adventures, they reunite and marry; Pietro Boccamazza and Agnolella, separated and beset with dangers, are finally married; Ricciardo is found with Messer Lizio’s daughter and marries her; a girl is claimed as a foundling, courted by two men, her parentage is revealed, and all wed happily; Gianni di Procida and Restituta, separated and both threatened with death, are reunited and married; an unnoticed damsel Lisa loves King Pedro, is brought to his attention by a song, and is happily married; Nastagio degli Onesti, after seeing a vision of tormented lovers, frightens his beloved into accepting him; Federigo degli Alberighi, having become poor, cooks his prized falcon for the woman he loves, and, moved by his generosity, she marries him; and Pietro di Vinciolo’s wife is caught with her lover, but through wit, harmonizes her marriage.

---

**Day 6:** *Topic: Those who used quick wit to escape loss, danger, or shame*

Highlights include a lady’s clever riposte to a tedious storyteller; Cisti the baker, with a subtle response, exposes the folly of a nobleman who requests wine; Madonna Nonna de’ Pulci jests with a bishop who offends her honor; Chichibio the cook excuses himself for a missing crane leg with a witty reply; Messer Forese and Giotto humorously insult each other’s appearance; Michele Scalza proves, through comic logic, that the baronci (vagabonds) are the noblest in Florence; Madonna Filippa, charged with adultery, saves her life with a clever answer and changes the law; Uncle Fresco wittily rebukes his vain niece; Guido Cavalcanti outwits his would-be tormentors with a sharp retort; and Fra Cipolla, exposed as a charlatan, skillfully improvises to maintain his dignity.

---

**Day 7:** *Topic: Tricks women have played on their husbands (or vice versa)*

A series of comedic tales: Gianni Lotteringhi’s wife convinces him a late-night knock is a ghost; Peronella hides her lover in a wine vat from her husband and tricks him into cleaning it; Fra Rinaldo, caught by his gossip’s husband, pretends to be performing a conjuration to exorcise worms; Ghita tricks her jealous husband Tofano into locking himself out and then humiliates him; a jealous husband, disguised as a confessor, tricks his wife into revealing her affair, but she turns the tables; Isabella ingeniously gets her lover and another suitor out of her house when her husband returns; Lodovico wins Beatrice with her help, cuckolding her husband Egano and beating him in disguise; a wife signals her lover with a thread, but her husband discovers the trick and is outwitted when she makes him punish her maid instead; Lydia tricks her husband Nicostratus and sleeps with his servant Pyrrhus; two friends love the same woman, one dies, and returns as a ghost, relating the afterlife.

---

**Day 8:** *Topic: Tricks played by anyone on anyone*

Stories include Gulfardo tricking a merchant’s wife into sleeping with him for her own husband’s money; a priest is tricked into losing his cloak as “pledge” for sex and must use a new trick to recover it; Calandrino is fooled by Bruno and Buffalmacco into thinking he’s found a magic stone of invisibility; a priest is tricked by a clever widow and ends up bedding her ugly servant while she exposes him to the bishop; Maso and his friends publicly shame a foreign judge by pulling down his breeches; Calandrino, convinced he’s with child, is fleeced by his friends for “medicines”; Cecco Fortarrigo robs Angiolieri and abandons him en route to the Marches; Calandrino is seduced by a serving-woman and caught by his wife; two men stay at an inn, each sleeping with the other's wife by confusion, but it is skillfully resolved; a wife ignores her husband’s warning dream and is disfigured as predicted; Ciacco tricks Biondello into being beaten by Messer Filippo in revenge for a dinner; Solomon advises one man to "love" to be loved, and another to "Goosebridge" (beat his wife), each getting what he seeks; and finally, Dom Gianni tricks Pietro into believing he can turn his wife into a mare (and nearly seduces her) but is thwarted when Pietro objects to the tail.

---

**Day 9:** *Topic: Free choice – any story desired*

Tales include: Francesca cleverly avoids two suitors using a ruse with a tomb; an abbess, rushing to catch a nun in bed with her lover, accidentally exposes her own affair and is outwitted; Calandrino, convinced by friends he is pregnant, is conned into giving them gifts for medicine; Fortarrigo cheats his friend out of everything, including his clothes, and abandons him; Calandrino, infatuated with a serving-wench, is conned and badly beaten by his wife; Pinuccio and Adriano stay at an inn, resulting in a series of mistaken bedmates and confusion resolved by the innkeeper’s clever wife; Talano warns his wife of a dream, which comes true when she is attacked by a wolf; Ciacco avenges himself on Biondello for a dinner with a humiliating prank; and a tale of two men who, seeking wisdom from Solomon, are taught to "love" and to "beat their wives" with various results; finally, Dom Gianni’s attempt at magic backfires.

---

**Day 10:** *Topic: Acts of generosity or magnificence*

Stories: A knight, feeling unrewarded, is shown by the King of Spain that it is fortune, not the king’s will, that determines gifts; Ghino di Tacco, a famous robber, captures the abbot of Cluny, cures his ailment, treats him generously and is rewarded by the Pope; Mithridanes envies Nathan’s reputation and generosity and plans to kill him, but Nathan, discovering the plot, is willing to die for him, and they become friends; Messer Gentile, in love with a married lady who is believed dead, discovers her buried alive, restores her life, and then, with great magnanimity, returns her and her child to her husband; Messer Ansaldo, loving a married lady, uses magic to fulfill her impossible wish, but when her husband allows her to honor her promise to Ansaldo, the latter and the magician both forgive her; King Charles falls in love with a peasant girl, but, shamed by this, instead arranges for the noble marriages of her and her sister; King Pedro of Aragon learns of the love of a common girl Lisa for him, rewards her with a noble marriage and is ever after her devoted friend; the Roman Titus loves his friend Gisippus's bride, Gisippus gives up his bride to Titus, and after many adversities, they are all united and fortune is restored; Torello of Istria, having entertained the disguised Saladin, is captured in the Crusades, is recognized by Saladin, and by magic is returned to his wife just as she is about to remarry, after which he is reunited with her; and, finally, Gualtieri, Marquess of Saluzzo, marries the peasant Griselda, subjects her to years of cruel tests of loyalty and patience, including feigned murder of her children and apparent divorce, but at last reveals the tests, and Griselda is rewarded for her steadfastness.

---

**Conclusion:**
After ten days (and ten stories per day, totaling 100 stories), the company, satisfied with their sojourn, decides to return to Florence. Each ruler of each day had chosen the day’s theme and overseen the amusements; as they depart, the author addresses the ladies for whom he wrote, responds to possible criticisms, and draws the work to a close.

---

**End of Plot Summary**
